metadata.title: Enhancement in hydrogen molecule adsorption on B12N12 nano-cluster by decoration of nickel

sections.text:

Available online at w

Enhancement in hydrogen molecule adsorption on B12N12 nano-cluster by decoration of nickel
Ali Shokuhi Rad a,*, Khurshid Ayub b
a Department of Chemical Engineering, Qaemshahr Branch, Islamic Azad University, Qaemshahr, Iran b Department of Chemistry, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, University Road, Tobe Camp, 22060 Abbottabad, Pakistan
a r t i c l e i n f o

sections.heading: Article history:
sections.text: Received 20 June 2016 Received in revised form 20 August 2016 Accepted 22 August 2016 Available online xxx

sections.heading: Keywords:
sections.text:
Nano-cluster B12N12 Metal decoration Density functional theory Hydrogen adsorption Thin solid film
* Corresponding author. Fax: þ98 111323677 E-mail addresses: a.shokuhi@gmail.com,
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2016.08.1 0360-3199/© 2016 Hydrogen Energy Publicati
Please cite this article in press as: Rad AS, Ay of nickel, International Journal of Hydrogen
a b s t r a c t
We present here results from detailed investigation on the adsorption property of H2 on the surface of B12N12 (BN) and Ni-decorated B12N12 (Ni-BN) nano-clusters through density functional theory (DFT) methods. First, the adsorption of Ni on BN nano-cage resulted in optimization of two distinct geometries (P1 and P2) differing in orientation of nickel on the surface of the nano-cage. The binding properties have been calculated and analyzed theoretically for both geometries of Ni-BN (P1 and P2) in terms of binding energies, band structures, total density of states, and natural bond orbital (NBO) charges. The nickel binds more strongly to BN nano-cage in P1 compared to P2, as revealed from energetic and electronic properties. Hydrogen adsorption has also been studied on Ni-BN (both P1 and P2), and compared with that of bare BN nano-cage. H2 adsorption capacity for nickel decorated BN nano-cage (Ni-BN) is considerably enhanced while there is very low adsorption capacity for pristine BN. Although, decoration of Ni in P1 geometry releases slightly higher energy (~444 kJ/mol versus ~399 kJ/mol for P2), the latter is better adsorbent for H2 molecule. H2 adsorption on Ni-BN in P2 geometry is more exothermic (~144 kJ/mol versus ~108 kJ/mol for position P1). The band gap of Ni-BN nano-cages increases upon interaction with hydrogen, and the effect is more pronounced for P2 geometry compared to P1. Incorporation of Ni enhances the H2 adsorption capacity of BN cluster, significantly.
© 2016 Hydrogen Energy Publications LLC. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Adsorption of H2 on transition metals such as Pt and Ni is a fundamental aspect of numerous chemical processes. For instance, hydrogenation, de-hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis are a few key reactions in chemical industries involving interaction of H2 with metallic surfaces. Majority of the above-mentioned reactions generally happen on the surface of heterogeneous transition metal catalysts [1e3], and
35. a.shokuhi@qaemiau.ac.ir 58 ons LLC. Published by Els
ub K, Enhancement in hy Energy (2016), http://dx.d
depend on the adsorption behavior of H2 molecule onmetallic surface. Moreover, H2 interaction with transition metals is imperative to phenomena such as H2 storage and its purification [4,5].
Sub-surface hydrogen has been shown to play dominant role in some chemical reactions, particularly hydrogenation reactions on nickel and on palladium nanoparticles [6e10]. Therefore, a deep understanding of hydrogen interactionwith transition metals is very important for different applications. The interaction of H2 with different surfaces of Pd [11], Ru [12],
(A.S. Rad).
evier Ltd. All rights reserved.
drogenmolecule adsorption on B12N12 nano-cluster by decoration oi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2016.08.158
Fe [13], Pt [14], and Ni [15,16] are already reported in the literature. Moreover, several metallic hydrides have also been studied for hydrogenation reaction. Applications of metal hydrides for hydrogen-storage are excellently presented in a review article by Sakintuna et al. [17]. In another report, Kalamse et al. [18] studied the interaction of H2 with C2H2Ni, C2H4Ni complex and also with their dimer using density functional method.
Experimentally, Shivram and Phillips [19,20] have investigated the interaction of hydrogen molecule with Ti doped ethylene and benzene complexes via nano-gravimetry method. Generally, these studies are restricted on dissociation and adsorption of H2 on mentioned surfaces. Ferrin et al. [21] performed a comprehensive study on interaction of hydrogenwith different facets of seventeen transitionmetals. Yarovsky and his co-worker also reported the adsorption properties of H2 on Al13 cluster. They concluded that this cluster can be used for H2 storage [22]. Jagiello et al. [23] used DFT calculation to investigate the potential of porous carbons for H2 adsorption.
Discovery of carbon nanotubes by Ijimia brought a quick development in the field of nano-scale carbon materials [24]. Besides applications of carbon nano-tube and fullerene C60 in advanced materials, extensive research have been carried out to synthesize spherical or tubular fullerenes of diverse noncarbon inorganic materials. For example boron nitride (BN) [25], and silica [26]and aluminum nitride (AlN) [27] and coaxial cubic AlNeBN composite nanotubes [28] are a few examples in this regard.
These nano-clusters are subject of several recent investigations [29e31] because these clusters with closed electronic shells are extremely stable and potentially important building blocks for advanced materials. Based on different theoretical studies on (XY)n clusters, the fullerene-like cages X12Y12(X ¼ B, Al, Ga, and Y ¼ N, P, As) are known as the most stable clusters [32,33]. Jensen and Toftlund [34] investigated various geometries of B12N12 using ab-initio calculation, and they concluded that B12N12 cluster is characterized by superior stability compared to analogous C24. B12N12 cluster was synthesized by Oku et al. [35], and detected by laser desorption time-of-flight mass spectrometry. These nano-structures are excellent adsorbent and sensor for a variety of molecules.
In our recent research [36], we have investigated the adsorption of guanine molecule on the surface of four nanocages through DFT calculations. We found that despite Al12N12 has the highest adsorption energy; B12N12 and B12P12 showmore changes in electronic property upon adsorption of guanine. Spherical non-carbon nano-cages can also be used for hydrogen storage. For example, Guo et al. have found that a hydrogen molecule interacts with AlN cages with considerable adsorption energy [37]. The capability of AlN nanostructures to store hydrogen has also been studied by Wang et al. [38].
In the recent past, numerous theoretical reports have appeared on metal decorated or doped nanostructures [39e44], besides pure nanostructures. We have reported the adsorption of nickel on the surface of Al12P12 [45]. We found that there are four possible sites for decoration of nickel atom. Moreover, it was found that doping of transition metal increases the hydrogen storage potential of clusters [46]. In
Please cite this article in press as: Rad AS, Ayub K, Enhancement in hy of nickel, International Journal of Hydrogen Energy (2016), http://dx.d
particular Ti, V, Ni, and Pd were extensively utilized in the hydrogenation reaction. Moreover, Pd/AlN/SiC, Pd/AlN/SiO2 and PdeNi/AlN/n Sinano-composites have also been used for hydrogen storage and hydrogen sensing [47e49].
Zhang et al. [50] investigated the feasibility of bare and Ni decorated Al12N12 cages for hydrogen storage. They found that at Al12N12 cage, each Al atom is able to adsorb one H2 in molecular form, while in the Ni decorated Al12N12 cage, the most stable site for Ni atom has been found to adsorb up to three hydrogen molecules.
In the current study, we examine the adsorption of H2 on the surface of BN and Ni-BN nano-cages. First, we explore the geometric and electronic properties of BN surfaces upon decoration of Ni by examining binding energies, the charge transfer, density of states, dipole moments and adsorption geometries for each position. Then, the relaxed Ni-BN clusters are theoretically investigated for H2 adsorption. Moreover we also discuss the dissociative or non-dissociative adsorption on the surface of BN and Ni-BN nano-cages. This is the first systematic DFT study of hydrogen adsorption on BN nano-cages.

sections.heading: Computational methods
sections.text:
All calculations were performed using Gaussian 09 suite of program [51] using DFT at B3LYP/6-31G (d,p) functional/basis set. Geometry optimization, density of states (DOS), charge transfer, the molecular electrostatic potential (MEP), and HOMOeLUMO distribution were performed to investigate the adsorption phenomena. B3LYP is a well-known, accurate and frequently used functional for nanostructures like X12Y12 [34,44,52]. We have searched on the influence of Ni-decorating on the electronic properties of BN cluster. A number of possible orientation are considered for decoration of Ni on BN nano-cage but all input geometries resulted in optimization of two structures namely P1 and P2 (vide infra). The adsorption energy of Ni on the BN in both positions is calculated by:
Ead ¼ ENi-BN ðEBN þ ENiÞ (1) where ENi-BN is the total (electronic) energy of BN interacting with the Ni and EBN is total energy of an isolated BN, and ENi is the total electronic energy of an isolated Ni. The interaction energy of H2 with isolated BN and Ni-BN is calculated by:
Eint ðBNÞ ¼ EH2 BN EBN þ EH2
(2)
Eint ðNi-BNÞ ¼ EH2 Ni-BN ENi-BN þ EH2
(3)
Where Eint(BN) and Eint(Ni-BN) correspond to interaction energy of H2 with BN and Ni-BN, EH2 BN and EH2 Ni BN are total electronic energies of BN and Ni-BN interacting with the H2, and EH2 is the total energy of an isolated H2.
Parr et al. [53] mentioned the electrophilicity concept for the first time in 1999. Chemical potential (m) is defined as [54]:
m ¼ 1=2 ðEHOMO þ ELUMOÞ (4) where EHOMO and ELUMO are the energies of HOMO and LUMO, respectively. Moreover, hardness (s) could be considered using the Koopmans' theorem [54] as:

s ¼ 1=2 ELUMO EHOMO
(5)
Softness (S) [54] and electrophilicity (u) [54] are calculated
by Eqs. (6) and (7), respectively.
S ¼ 1=2 s (6)
u ¼ m2=2 s (7)

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
We studied the effect of nickel decoration on the geometric and electronic properties of boron nitride (BN) nano-cages. The geometries of bare and nickel decorated BN nano-cages are optimized at B3LYP functional at 6-31G(d,p) basis set. The optimized geometry of BN nano-cage is shown in Fig. 1. The geometric parameters of bare BN nano-cage agree well with the already reported data [34,52]. A number of different possible orientations of nickel on the surface of boron nitride (BN) nano-cage are studied. These orientations include placement of nickel atom on an atom (B or N), a bond or a ring of nano-cage. These orientations are denoted as M@B, M@N, M@b66, M@b64, M@r4 and M@r6. M@B and M@N are the orientations where nickel is placed on top of boron and nitrogen atoms of the nano-cage, respectively. M@b66 and M@b64 are the orientations where nickel atom is placed on bond shared between two six-membered ring, and a six- and fourmembered ring, respectively. M@r4 and M@r6 are the orientations where nickel atom is placed above four-membered and six-membered ring, respectively. Although six different orientations are possible for placement of nickel on BN nanocage, only two geometries were optimized; M@b64 (P1) and M@b66 (P2) (Fig. 2). All other input geometries relaxed to these two structures during the optimization process. This behavior of BN nano-cages is quite contrary to AlP nano-cage. Themost stable orientation for nickel adsorption on AlP nano-cage is M@r6 followed by M@r4 (orientations which are elusive for Ni decoration on BNnano-cage). Thismarked difference between the behaviors of these nano-cages can be attributed to small ring size for six and four membered rings of BN nano-cages. The small ring size of BN nano-cage does not allow for suitable interaction of nickel with the atoms in the ring. However,
Please cite this article in press as: Rad AS, Ayub K, Enhancement in hy of nickel, International Journal of Hydrogen Energy (2016), http://dx.d
the larger ring size of AlP nano-cage provides enough room for coordination of phosphorus atom of the nano-cage with nickel atom.
Among the two geometries optimized for nickel adsorbed BN nano-cage, P1 geometry is more stable than P2. This observation is consistent with our results on AlP nano-cage where P1 orientation is found more stable than P2 geometry [35]. The greater stability of P1 geometry compared to P2 can be attributed mainly to the interaction distance of nickel with the nano-cage. In P1, the nickel is situated at a distance of 1.37 A from the nano-cage. On the other hand, the nickel in P2 geometry is present at a distance of 1.6 A from the nano-cage. From the close analysis of the geometry of P1, it is revealed that adsorption of nickel on the surface of BN nano-cages causes elongation of the bond on which nickel is adsorbed (bond connecting four and six membered ring). The BeN bond connecting four and six membered ring is 1.48 Å in bare BN nano-cage which gets elongated to 2.32 Å in Ni decorated BN nano-cage (P1 geometry). The slightly strained fourmembered ring of the BN nano-cage gets converted into an envelope like five membered ring in Ni-BN nano-cage (P1). The loss in strain is probably responsible for higher stability of P1 over P2. The other bond lengths in the nano-cage are almost unaffected by nickel decoration. The change in bond length in P2 geometry is very small; the bond on which nickel is adsorbed (bond connecting two six membered rings) is stretched to 1.64 A in P2 compared to 1.43 Å in bare BN nano-cage.
The nickel adsorption energies in P1 and P2 orientations are 444.3 and 399.1 kJ/mol, respectively. The high interaction energies are indicative of chemisorption of nickel on BN nano-cage. The high adsorption energy of Ni in P1 also causes more shifts in NBO charges compared to P2 geometry. The NBO charge on nickel in P1 geometry is þ0.66 compared to þ0.58 in P2. Surprisingly, the dipole moment of P2 geometry is higher (3.79 D) than P1 (3.50 D). The dipole moments are shown to have inverse relationship with the binding energies. This inverse relationship can be explained based on the distance of nickel from the nano-cage. The large distance in P2, although results in lower binding energies, but causes larger dipole moment due to large vector.
Then, we studied the adsorption of H2 on bare BN nanocage, and compared these results with those for Nidecorated BN nano-cages (P1 and P2). Interaction of H2 on bare BN is very weak. The interaction energy of H2 with pristine BN nano-cage is merely 1.7 kJ/mol. The H2 molecule is oriented perpendicular to BN nano-cage where only one hydrogen atom interacts with the nano-cage at a distance of 2.83 Å (Table 1). The HeH bond distance is 0.74 A and it is identical to isolated H2 molecule.
The adsorption of hydrogenmolecule onM@b64 nano-cage (P1) is highly exothermic by 108.4 kJ/mol. Both hydrogen atoms of H2 molecule interact with nickel atom which results in considerable elongation of HeH bond to 0.85 Å from 0.74 A in isolated H2 molecule, so we can see partial dissociation of H2 upon adsorption. Both hydrogen atoms are equidistant to nickel (1.54 Å, see Fig. 3). Adsorption of H2 on P2 geometry is more exothermic ( 143.9 kJ/mol) than that of P1 ( 108.4 kJ/ mol). In addition, the value achieved for H2 adsorption on P2 geometry is grater compared to that reported for single H2 adsorption on Ni-decorated (~ 130.9 kJ/mol) [50]. For both
drogenmolecule adsorption on B12N12 nano-cluster by decoration oi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2016.08.158
Table 1 e Selected geometric parameters of relaxed structure: the equilibrium distance of adsorbed Ni or H2, transferred charge of adsorbed Ni on BN and also H2 on BN as well as Ni-BN based on NBO (QNBO), dipole moment (mD) and adsorption energy (Ead)of different systems. System dae (A ) Q b NBO (e) mD (Debye) E c ad (kJ/mol)
Free BN e e 0.00 e Ni-BN (P1) 1.37 þ0.66 3.50 444.3 Ni-BN (P2) 1.61 þ0.58 3.79 399.1 BN-H2 2.83 0.05 2.88 1.7 Ni-BN (P1)-H2 1.54 0.01 3.21 108.4 Ni-BN (P2)-H2 1.50 0.05 2.88 143.9 a The distance of Ni to BN (for Ni adsorption) and the distance of H2 to Ni (for H2 adsorption). b The charge transfer upon Ni adsorption (for H2-free systems) and
upon H2 adsorption (for H2 included systems). c The calculated energy upon Ni adsorption (for H2-free systems)
and upon H2 adsorption for all H2 included systems.
geometries, the values of calculated adsorption energy are greater than that experimentally reported for H2 adsorption on (111) plane of nickel (~ 95 kJ/mol) [55], Ni(111) (~ 96 kJ/ mol) and Ni(100) (~ 90 kJ/mol) single crystal surfaces [56].
Both hydrogen atoms are equidistant in this geometry as well, and the bond lengths are 1.50 Å. HeH bond is further stretched to 0.88 Å, compared to 0.85 Å in P1. The hydrogen binding energies on Ni decorated nano-cages are inversely related to the Ni binding energies on BN nano-cages. Alternatively, the binding energies of H2 on Ni decorated nanocages are inversely relative to the stability of the Ni-BN nano-cages. Adsorption of H2 on more stable nano-cage (P1)
Please cite this article in press as: Rad AS, Ayub K, Enhancement in hy of nickel, International Journal of Hydrogen Energy (2016), http://dx.d
is less exothermic. Adsorption of nickel in P1 is more exothermic than P2 but the hydrogen absorption in P2 ismore exothermic than P1. It may be argued that the higher stability of P1 make the nickel adsorbed cluster less responsive towards further adsorption. The charge transfer QNBO is also very small for hydrogen adsorption. For bare BN nano-cage, the charge transfer is 0.05 which means the hydrogen molecule takes very little charge from the nano-cage. The QNBO for Ni-BN (P2)-H2 is also 0.05 but it reduces to 0.01 for Ni-BN (P1)-H2. The small amount of charge transfer in Ni-BN (P1)-H2 is consistent with its lower adsorption energy. Although the charge transferred on hydrogen adsorption is very small but, the change in dipole moment is very significant, particularly for P2 geometry of Ni-BN. The dipole moment of Ni-BN (P2) before hydrogen adsorption is 3.79 D which is reduced to 2.88 D after hydrogen adsorption. This may be attributed to the generation of slightly negative hydrogen atomswhich reduces the amount of positive charge at transition metal terminus of the nano-cage. The dipole moment of Ni-BN (P1) decreases from 3.50 to 3.21 D. This small change in dipole moment is consistent with small amount of negative charge transferred to hydrogen atoms which does not significantly decrease the polarity of Ni-BN (P1) nano-cage.
The effect of H2 adsorption on the electronic structure of the nano-cages can be seen in MEP map, shown in Fig. 4. The bare BN nano-cage has symmetrical potential (Fig. 4a), due to symmetrical structure. Boron atoms have positive potential (blue in color (in the web version)) and nitrogen atoms have negative potential (yellow color (in the web version)). Adsorption of H2 molecule in bare BN nano-cage causes intensification of positive charge in the cage. This is
drogenmolecule adsorption on B12N12 nano-cluster by decoration oi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2016.08.158
consistent with negative charge transfer on H2, which would leave positive charge on the nano-cage.
For P1 and P2, the nickel atom has positive potential whereas the atoms in the nano-cage have almost neutral potential. The negative potential on nitrogen and positive potential on boron in bare BN nano-cage is reduced in nickel decorated nano-cage in P1 and P2 geometries (compare Fig. 4b and c with 4a). Upon adsorption of hydrogen molecule, the negative potential is regenerated on the nano-cage (compare Fig. 4e with 4b, and 4f with 4c). This change in potential
Please cite this article in press as: Rad AS, Ayub K, Enhancement in hy of nickel, International Journal of Hydrogen Energy (2016), http://dx.d
corroborate nicely with drop in dipole moment for Ni-BN (P1)H2 and Ni-BN (P2)-H2 compared to Ni-BN (P1) and Ni-BN (P2), respectively. The MEP analysis also reveals that upon hydrogen adsorption, the position of positive potential also shifts to close proximity of nickel. In Ni-BN (P1) andNi-BN (P2), the region of positive potential is directly on top of Ni which shifts to sides after hydrogen adsorption.
Subsequently, the HOMOeLUMO distribution are scrutinized to study the outcome of adsorption of nickel on the nano-cage, as well as for the effect of hydrogen adsorption on
drogenmolecule adsorption on B12N12 nano-cluster by decoration oi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2016.08.158
pure and Ni decorated BN nano-cages. Energies of highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO), band gap (Eg) and Fermi level (EFL) are given in Table 2. Moreover the shapes of HOMOs and LUMOs are given in Fig. 5. Fermi level (EFL) in a molecule (at T ¼ 0 K) is approximately located at the mid of the HOMOeLUMO energy gap (Eg). The BN nano-cage is a large band gap semiconductor (Eg ¼ 6.85 eV) whereas nickel is a metal with very small HOMOeLUMO gap (0.22 eV). The HOMO and LUMO of BN nano-cages have energies of 7.71 and 0.86 eV, respectively. The HOMO and LUMO of nickel, on the other hand, have energies of 5.82 and 5.60 eV. The HOMO and LUMO in BN nano-cage are uniformly dispersed over the entire skeleton of the nano-cage. The effect of hydrogen adsorption on bare BN nano-cage is almost negligible.
Decoration of Ni on nano-cage brings quite significant changes regarding both, energies and densities. Adsorption of nickel atom on the surface of BN nano-cages decreases the energy of LUMO but increases the energy of HOMO which ultimately results in decrease in the band gap. The energies of HOMO and LUMO in P1 orientation are 5.81 and 2.65 eV which results in a band gap of 3.16 eV. The Fermi level is located at 4.23 eV. The effect of nickel adsorption on HOMOeLUMO gap is more pronounced in P2 geometry where the band gap is reduced to 2.83 eV. The energies of HOMO and LUMO are 5.33 and 2.50 eV, respectively. The difference in band gaps for P1 and P2 geometries mainly arise due to difference in energies of HOMO. As mentioned above, the HOMO is destabilized on adsorption of nickel whereas LUMO is stabilized. The HOMO in P1 is less destabilized ( 5.81 eV) compared to HOMO in P2 ( 5.33 eV). The effect on the LUMO is very comparable in P1 and P2 however; the LUMO in P1 is of lower energy than P2.
Wehave analyzed the shapes of frontier orbitals to account for this difference. In general, the HOMO is shifted to nickel metal upon adsorption. This is mainly due to the fact that coordination of nitrogen of the nano-cagewith themetal gives the superficial d electrons of Ni to turn into more diffuse excess electron which amplifies the energy level of newly formed HOMO. The location of densities of HOMO on metal center is supportive to our notion. Stronger coordination of Ni with BN nano-cage in P1 would render the HOMO more destabilized in P1, compared to bare BN nano-cage. It might be possible that the excess electrons are donated back to the nano-cage through back donation. The location of some electron density on nano-cage in P1 geometry is also supportive to our notion. No such density is seen on nano-cage in
Table 2e The orbital parameters: HOMO energies (EHOMO), LUMO energies (ELUMO), energy of Fermi level (EFL), HOMOeLUMO energy gap (Eg) for different systems.
System EHOMO (eV) E FL (eV) E LUMO (eV) Eg (eV)
Ni 5.82 5.71 5.60 0.22 BN 7.71 4.28 0.86 6.85 Ni-BN (P1) 5.81 4.23 2.65 3.16 Ni-BN (P2) 5.33 3.91 2.50 2.83 BN-H2 7.73 4.31 0.89 6.84 Ni-BN (P1)-H2 6.29 4.04 1.79 4.50 Ni-BN (P2)-H2 6.01 3.66 1.32 4.69
Please cite this article in press as: Rad AS, Ayub K, Enhancement in hy of nickel, International Journal of Hydrogen Energy (2016), http://dx.d
P2 geometry. The LUMO is also shiftedmainly to Ni atom in P1 and P2 geometry but it has some density on the nano-cage as well. Location of higher electron density on the nano-cage in P1 is probably the reason for more stabilization of LUMO compared to P2.
Adsorption behavior of hydrogen on bare and Ni decorated BN nano-cages is mixed. For pristine BN nano-cage, the band gap is almost the same on hydrogen adsorption but for Ni-BN (P1)-H2 and Ni-BN (P2)-H2 band gap increases to 4.50 eV and 4.69 eV from 3.16 eV to 2.83 eV, respectively.
The change in band gap on hydrogen adsorption is mainly due to stabilization of HOMO and slightly due to destabilization of LUMO. These effects are more pronounced in P2 geometry compared to P1 which again correlates well with the high adsorption energies of H2 in P2 compared to P1. Densities on HOMO and LUMO in Ni-BN (P1)-H2 and Ni-BN (P2)-H2 are not significantly different than those in Ni-BN (P1) and Ni-BN (P2). It may be argued that hydrogen adsorption reduces the pull of nickel atom from BN nano-cage (or increases the back donation of electron to the nano-cage) which would eventually give rise to more stabilized HOMO. Interestingly, the density in H2 adsorbed BN nano-cages move away from the nitrogen interacting with H2 molecule.
Next, we analyzed the densities of states to realize how the adsorption of Ni affects the electronic structure of bare BN nano-cage. Moreover, the perturbation of electronic structure of bare and Ni decorated BN nano-cages by hydrogen adsorption can also be estimated from the densities of states. The densities of states for pure, Ni doped BN nano-cages are compared with their hydrogen adsorbed complexes in Fig. 6. By comparison, it is observed that doping of a nickel atom causes significant shift of the occupied orbitals of BN nanocage to high energy levels and the newly formed HOMOs lie between the original HOMO and LUMO of BN nano-cage. Adsorption of nickel on BN nano-cage not only shifts the orbitals but the intensities also change. The intensities of peaks in the region of HOMO and LUMO decrease for both P1 and P2. The effect is almost comparable in both geometries. After hydrogen adsorption, the density of states graph reverts back slightly to bare BNnano-cage. Not only the peaksmove out but also the intensities start increasing. The effect of H2 adsorption on reversion of density of states is more pronounced for P1 compared to P2, which is very consistent with the effect on band gap.
The change in band gap leads to changes in conductivity. Relationship between conductivity and Eg can be given by the following equation [57].
s a exp Eg=kT
(8)
where s is the electric conductivity and k corresponds to the Boltzmann constant. It can be seen clearly that a small decrease in Eg leads to significantly higher electrical conductivities. From the results above, one can easily conclude that bare BN nano-cage is not a good sensor for hydrogenmolecule but adsorption of nickel on BN nano-cage significantly enhances its ability towards hydrogen adsorption.
We have also evaluated the global indices of reactivity in order to evaluate how the adsorption of nickel affects the chemical properties of BN nano-cages. Moreover the effect of
drogenmolecule adsorption on B12N12 nano-cluster by decoration oi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2016.08.158
hydrogen adsorption on the chemical properties of Ni decorated BN nano-cages can also be realized from these global indices of reactivity. The m, S, s and u of nickel decorated BN nano-cage are prepared in Table 3 and contrasted with pure and hydrogen adsorbed BN nano-cage. The energies of HOMO can approximately be taken equivalent to ionization potential (according to Koopmann theorem [54]) whereas the energies of LUMO correspond to electron affinity. The ionization potential for BN nano-cage is very high (7.71 eV) which further
Please cite this article in press as: Rad AS, Ayub K, Enhancement in hy of nickel, International Journal of Hydrogen Energy (2016), http://dx.d
increases to 7.73 eV upon adsorption of hydrogen. Decoration of the nano-cage with nickel causes reduction in ionization potential. The ionization potentials of nickel decorated complexes P1 and P2 are 5.81 and 5.33 eV. The ionization potential, however, increases again when hydrogen molecule is adsorbed on nickel decorated BN nano-cages P1 and P2. A similar behavior is also observed for electron affinities. Since ionization potential and electron affinities are directly related to the energies of HOMO and LUMO, respectively therefore, trends in
drogenmolecule adsorption on B12N12 nano-cluster by decoration oi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2016.08.158
Table 3 e Chemical potential (m), hardness (s), softness (S), and electrophilicity (u) of relaxed structure of Ni adsorbed on BN at P1, and P2 configurations along with their complexes with H2. All parameters are in units of eV.
Property Ni BN Ni-BN (P1) Ni-BN (P2) BN-H2 Ni-BN (P1)-H2 Ni-BN (P2)-H2 [I ¼ EHOMO]/eV 5.82 7.71 5.81 5.33 7.73 6.29 6.01 [A ¼ ELUMO]/eV 5.60 0.86 2.65 2.50 0.89 1.79 1.32 [s ¼ (I A)/2]/eV 0.11 3.42 1.58 1.41 3.42 2.25 2.34 [m ¼ (I þ A)/2]/eV 5.71 4.28 4.23 3.91 4.31 4.04 3.66 [S ¼ 1/2s]/eV 1 4.54 0.15 0.32 0.35 0.15 0.22 0.21 [u ¼ m2/2s]/eV 148.02 2.75 5.72 5.35 2.79 3.59 2.81
these properties can be judged from the trends in the energies of HOMO and LUMOs. The band gap is indicative of the softness or hardness of a compound. A compoundwith large band gap is expected to be hard, and vice versa. The band gap decreases for Ni adsorbed BN nano-cages in P1 and P2 geometries. Therefore, it is expected that these complexes are very soft. Indeed this is the case. The complexes P1 and P2 have softness values of 0.35 and 0.32 eV 1. The softness decreases when hydrogen is adsorbed on these Ni adsorbed nano-cages (P1 and P2). The softness of Ni-BN (P1)-H2 and Ni-BN (P2)-H2 are 0.22 and 0.21 eV 1, respectively. The increase in chemical reactivity is electrophilic in nature because the
Please cite this article in press as: Rad AS, Ayub K, Enhancement in hy of nickel, International Journal of Hydrogen Energy (2016), http://dx.d
electrophilicities of Ni doped nano-cages are higher than the pure nano-cage. The P1 geometry has the highest electrophilicity of 5.72 eV followed by P2where electrophilicity of 5.35 eV is observed.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
We have investigated the possibility of bare and Ni-decorated BN nano-cage for H2 storage by DFT calculations. Firstly we investigated on the possible positions of Ni on BN nano-cage. Among the two geometries optimized for Ni adsorbed BN
drogenmolecule adsorption on B12N12 nano-cluster by decoration oi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2016.08.158
nano-cage, P1 geometry is more stable than P2. The high interaction energies are indicative of chemisorption of Ni on BN nano-cage. The high adsorption energy of Ni in P1 also causes more shifts in NBO charges compared to P2 geometry. Then, we studied the adsorption of H2 on bare BN nano-cage, and compared these results with those for Ni-decorated BN nano-cages (P1 and P2). Actually Interaction of H2 on bare BN is very weak but its interaction is considerable on Nidecorated BN at both position. Moreover we found that P2 geometry is more exothermic ( 143.9 kJ/mol) than that of P1 ( 108.4 kcal mol 1) upon adsorption of H2. Our results show partial dissociation of H2 when it adsorbed on the surface of nickel decorated BN.

[51] Frisch MJ, Trucks GW, Schlegel HB, Scuseria GE, Robb MA, Cheeseman JR, et al.
[52] Beheshtian J, Bagheri Z, Kamfiroozi M, Ahmadi A.
[56] Christmann K, Schober O, Ertl G, Neumann M.

metadata.abstractText: We present here results from detailed investigation on the adsorption property of H2 on the surface of B12N12 (BN) and Ni-decorated B12N12 (Ni-BN) nano-clusters through density functional theory (DFT) methods. First, the adsorption of Ni on BN nano-cage resulted in optimization of two distinct geometries (P1 and P2) differing in orientation of nickel on the surface of the nano-cage. The binding properties have been calculated and analyzed theoretically for both geometries of Ni-BN (P1 and P2) in terms of binding energies, band structures, total density of states, and natural bond orbital (NBO) charges. The nickel binds more strongly to BN nano-cage in P1 compared to P2, as revealed from energetic and electronic properties. Hydrogen adsorption has also been studied on Ni-BN (both P1 and P2), and compared with that of bare BN nano-cage. H2 adsorption capacity for nickel decorated BN nano-cage (Ni-BN) is considerably enhanced while there is very low adsorption capacity for pristine BN. Although, decoration of Ni in P1 geometry releases slightly higher energy (~444 kJ/mol versus ~399 kJ/mol for P2), the latter is better adsorbent for H2 molecule. H2 adsorption on Ni-BN in P2 geometry is more exothermic (~144 kJ/mol versus ~108 kJ/mol for position P1). The band gap of Ni-BN nano-cages increases upon interaction with hydrogen, and the effect is more pronounced for P2 geometry compared to P1. Incorporation of Ni enhances the H2 adsorption capacity of BN cluster, significantly. © 2016 Hydrogen Energy Publications LLC. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
